content.title: EXPLORING RENEWABLE TECHNOLOGIES FOR CLIMATE MITIGATION

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview
EXPLORING RENEWABLE TECHNOLOGIES FOR CLIMATE MITIGATION

In this lesson, we will explore five key renewable energy technologies that are playing a pivotal role in climate mitigation and shaping the global energy transition. While there are numerous emerging and nascent technologies on the horizon, the focus here will be on those that are already having a significant impact or show strong potential to drive the transition to a low-carbon future. Understanding these technologies is crucial for advancing sustainable energy solutions and achieving the goals of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and limiting global warming.
Following these updated figures, we will take a closer look at five key renewable technologies, examining their advancements, applications, and role in the global energy transition.

content.intro: M6: SUSTAINABLE ENERGY FOR CLIMATE MITIGATION | chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1:  Solar Energy

content.text: Solar power is one of the cleanest and most abundant renewable energy sources available. It can be harnessed through various technologies, such as solar photovoltaics (PV), concentrated solar power (CSP), and solar thermal systems. Solar PV technology is the most widespread, transforming sunlight into electricity via silicon semiconductors. However, PV systems require battery storage to retain electricity for nighttime use. In 2023, solar PV accounted for three-quarters of all renewable power capacity additions, with global capacity reaching a record 473 gigawatts. CSP, on the other hand, uses mirrors to concentrate sunlight, generating heat for power production, and it can store energy for use at night. In 2020, CSP’s installed capacity reached 7 gigawatts, showing significant growth since 2010.

Solar power plays a critical role in reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. For example, solar PV produces about 43-45 grams of CO2 per kWh through its lifecycle as discussed in the previous chapter. When replacing fossil fuel power with solar PV, an acre of solar panels can save up to 198 metric tons of CO2 annually. Additionally, the cost of solar panels has dramatically dropped, with prices falling 93% from 2010 to 2020, making solar power the most affordable energy source in many regions.

The solar energy market has driven job creation as well. In 2023, approximately 7.1 million people were employed in solar PV, with China, dominating the workforce with 4.6 million jobs. Employment in clean energy continued to surpass fossil fuel jobs, reaching 34.8 million positions compared to 32.6 million in the fossil fuel sector.
Rising Energy Demand

Climate change does not just affect the production side, it also increases energy demand. 
Global energy demand grew at an above-average rate in 2024, driven by rising electricity consumption worldwide. Energy demand increased by 2.2%, outpacing the 1.3% annual average growth seen between 2013 and 2023, though still trailing global GDP growth of 3.2%. The power sector was the primary driver of this acceleration, with global electricity consumption rising by nearly 1,100 terawatt-hours (4.3%), almost double the previous decade’s annual average.

content.intro: M1: Just Energy Transition | chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title:
Part 2: 
Wind Energy

content.text:
Wind power harnesses the kinetic energy of the wind through turbines that convert it into electrical energy, producing minimal greenhouse gas emissions compared to other energy sources. Over the past decade, wind technology has seen significant innovations, improving efficiency, power, and capacity while reducing noise. Wind installations now include onshore, offshore, and floating platforms capable of withstanding extreme conditions, such as hurricane-force winds. Offshore wind, with its stronger and more consistent winds, is expected to grow as siting challenges are addressed. Wind power currently accounts for 6-7% of global electricity, with substantial potential to meet global energy needs.
Wind energy is a crucial component of global climate strategies, particularly under the IEA Net Zero Emissions (NZE) Scenario, as emphasized in the UAE Consensus, which calls for doubling energy efficiency and tripling renewable energy capacity by 2030. In 2022, wind power grew by 17%, contributing to a combined 12% share of global electricity generation alongside solar PV. Wind energy's near-zero greenhouse gas emissions and high energy return on energy invested (EROEI) make it an essential solution for reducing emissions.
Additionally, wind power supports job creation, particularly in China and Europe, with 1.4 million jobs in 2022. Wind turbines have an operational lifespan of 20 years, running nearly emissions-free after offsetting construction emissions within 3-6 months.
Case Study RBEC:                                                                                                                  Kazakhstan —Wind Power Market Development Initiative

The Wind Power Market Development Initiative, launched in 2004 by UNDP and GEF in collaboration with the Government of Kazakhstan, sought to establish a sustainable wind energy sector in Kazakhstan. This ambitious project aimed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions while tapping into the country's substantial wind energy potential, estimated at 929 billion kWh annually, equivalent to 154 GW of installed capacity. By the time the project concluded in 2011, it had laid critical groundwork for wind energy development, addressing systemic barriers and fostering a more favorable environment for renewable energy investment.
At the outset, the project faced significant obstacles. Awareness of wind energy’s potential was minimal, and technical capacity within the country was underdeveloped. There were no operational wind farms to provide a proof of concept, and financial barriers loomed large, including low electricity tariffs, high commercial risks, and challenges in securing both domestic and foreign investment. Institutional barriers further hindered progress, with an absence of dedicated policies, regulatory frameworks, and centralized mechanisms to promote and manage wind energy projects.

Despite these challenges, the initiative achieved transformative outcomes. It facilitated the creation of the National Wind Power Development Program, which set ambitious targets for wind energy generation, aiming for 750 million kWh by 2015 and 5 billion kWh by 2030. A wind atlas was developed and made publicly accessible, providing valuable data to investors and developers. Comprehensive studies on technical, environmental, and commercial aspects were conducted, including assessments of grid capacity and innovative financing mechanisms. 
These efforts ensured that no insurmountable obstacles stood in the way of wind energy development in Kazakhstan.

The project’s legacy includes a shift in government policies, culminating in the acknowledgment of the need for fixed feed-in tariffs to replace ad hoc, project-specific agreements. This policy change has the potential to reduce risks for developers and attract sustained investment in the sector. While feed-in tariffs were once a key tool for investment certainty, many markets are now shifting toward auction-based systems or moving away from subsidies altogether as renewable energy becomes increasingly cost-competitive.
The initiative also fostered capacity-building through training programs, enabling local professionals to acquire expertise in wind energy technologies, resource assessment, and project planning. Over 100 professionals were trained, and specialized software tools were introduced to streamline project development processes.
Significant progress was also made in engaging stakeholders, from government agencies to private investors. The establishment of partnerships with international and national organizations laid the foundation for ongoing collaboration and knowledge sharing. The project’s achievements underscore the importance of aligning technical expertise, regulatory frameworks, and financial incentives to foster renewable energy growth.

While much has been accomplished, challenges remain. Ensuring policy stability, enhancing grid infrastructure, and further refining financial mechanisms are critical for scaling up wind energy. Continued cooperation among government entities, international partners, and private sector stakeholders will be essential to build on the project’s success and fully realize Kazakhstan’s vast wind energy potential.
This case study highlights the transformative impact of targeted interventions in overcoming barriers to renewable energy development. By addressing systemic challenges and creating an enabling environment, the initiative has not only advanced Kazakhstan’s wind energy sector but also provided a valuable model for similar efforts in other emerging markets.

References                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Global Environment Facility. 2011. “Lessons Learnt from the UNDP-GEF Project ‘Kazakhstan — Wind Power Market Development Initiative.’” The United Nations Development Programme. Kazakhstan: UNDP Kazakhstan.

content.intro: M6: SUSTAINABLE ENERGY FOR CLIMATE MITIGATION | chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3:  Hydropower

content.text:
Hydropower is a significant renewable energy source that harnesses the potential energy of water flowing from higher to lower elevations. It can be categorized into different types, including storage dams and “run-of-river” systems. Large storage dams provide backup power and rapid response during outages, while run-of-river plants offer continuous base load energy. Hydropower is highly valuable for grid stability, providing fast-response generation and supporting frequency stability. However, its potential is influenced by climate-related changes in rainfall and ecosystems, with droughts posing a challenge. 

Hydropower offers substantial carbon emissions reductions, saving up to 4 billion tonnes of CO2 annually compared to coal. It accounts for about 9% of global CO2 emissions reduction. In the IEA Net Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario, hydropower continues to grow at an average rate of 4% annually. There remains considerable untapped potential for hydropower development. Global technical potential is estimated at 14,576 TWh/year, over four times current generation levels. Africa, in particular, holds vast undeveloped potential, offering significant opportunities for growth.

content.intro: M6: SUSTAINABLE ENERGY FOR CLIMATE MITIGATION | chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 3
content.title: Part 4:  Geothermal

content.text:
Geothermal energy provides reliable, base-load power and heating/cooling from a widely available resource. It offers sustainable production and generates cost-effective, dispatchable power, unaffected by climate conditions. Geothermal energy has lower greenhouse gas emissions compared to traditional base-load thermal generation. In off-peak periods, it can also help recharge battery-powered vehicles, further reducing CO2 emissions. 

Geothermal energy can become a key part of future electricity and heating systems, offering a clean and reliable energy source. Right now, geothermal meets less than 1% of global energy demand, and its use is mostly in countries with easily accessible, high-quality resources like the United States, Iceland, Indonesia, Türkiye, Kenya, and Italy.

Geothermal energy has the potential to significantly contribute to global electricity demand by 2050. Advancements in technology and reductions in project costs could enable the deployment of up to 800 gigawatts (GW) of geothermal capacity worldwide, generating nearly 6,000 terawatt-hours annually—equivalent to the current combined electricity consumption of the United States and India.​

A notable advantage of geothermal power is its ability to provide continuous, baseload electricity. Geothermal plants can operate at full capacity 24/7, offering a reliable energy source. In 2023, global geothermal capacity had a utilization rate exceeding 75%, significantly higher than wind power's less than 30% and solar photovoltaic's (PV) less than 15%. Additionally, geothermal plants can operate flexibly, aiding in grid stabilization and complementing intermittent renewable sources like solar PV and wind.​

The International Energy Agency (IEA) projects that, with appropriate support, costs for next-generation geothermal technologies could decrease by 80% by 2035. At this cost level, geothermal plants could produce electricity at approximately $50 per megawatt-hour (MWh), positioning them among the most affordable dispatchable low-emission electricity sources, comparable to or cheaper than hydro, nuclear, and bioenergy. Furthermore, geothermal energy would be highly competitive with solar and wind power when paired with battery storage.

content.intro: M6: SUSTAINABLE ENERGY FOR CLIMATE MITIGATION | chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 3
content.title: Part 5:  Hydrogen

content.text:
Hydrogen is a versatile energy carrier, with clean hydrogen produced from renewables helping sectors like long-haul transport, chemicals, and iron and steel. Blue hydrogen, made from natural gas through methods like steam methane reforming and autothermal reforming, produces CO2 but can capture and store it. Green hydrogen, produced through electrolysis using renewable electricity, has no harmful by-products. 

Hydrogen plays a fundamental role in mitigating sectors that have proven hard to abate. Global hydrogen demand grew by 3% in 2022 to 95 million tonnes.  There are mainly heavy industry, shipping, long-distance land transport, and aviation. Implementing clean hydrogen provides relatively low technical challenges in the refining and fertilizer sectors, as it can be a like-for-like substitution for others.  More than 393 agreements were made related to hydrogen in 2022.

content.intro: M6: SUSTAINABLE ENERGY FOR CLIMATE MITIGATION | chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 3
content.title: Part 6: Strategies to Overcome Challenges in Renewable Technology Implementation in Developing Countries

content.text: Here is a brief recap of several strategies to overcome challenges and accelerate the deployment of renewables in developing countries discussed in other modules..

content.title: KEY TAKEAWAYS
content.intro: Lesson 1 on THE IMPACT OF ENERGY SYSTEMS ON CLIMATE CHANGE

cards.title: Diverse Renewable Technologies are Key to Emission Reductions.
cards.description: Solar, wind, hydropower, geothermal, and hydrogen are playing a crucial role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and accelerating the global energy transition. Each technology has unique advantages, such as solar PV’s affordability, wind energy’s scalability, hydropower’s grid stability, geothermal’s reliability, and hydrogen’s potential for hard-to-abate sectors.

cards.title: Implementation Challenges Must Be Addressed.
cards.description: While renewable energy technologies offer significant benefits, their implementation faces challenges, including high initial investment costs, grid integration issues, financing constraints, and infrastructure limitations, particularly in developing countries.

cards.title: Strategic Approaches are Essential for Scaling Renewable Energy.
cards.description: Policy incentives, innovative financing (e.g., blended finance and concessional loans), infrastructure development (grid modernization and energy storage), capacity building, and community engagement are key strategies for scaling up renewable energy deployment, ensuring equitable access, and supporting a just energy transition.

lessons.title:
Renewables 2024
This report forecasts renewable energy deployment through 2030, tracking global progress toward tripling capacity while identifying key barriers to growth. It includes a special chapter on renewable fuels and their role in decarbonizing key sectors. Alongside market forecasts, it examines policy drivers, manufacturing trends, technology costs, hydrogen production, and renewable energy integration.

Climate Action Support 2024
This report examines national and regional efforts to enhance and  implement climate targets, and the related support provided by IRENA  through its various work packages, including those concerned with NDCs.

Climate Change 2022: Mitigation of Climate Change
The Working Group III report provides an updated global assessment of climate change mitigation progress and pledges, and examines the sources of global emissions. It explains developments in emission reduction and mitigation efforts, assessing the impact of national climate pledges in relation to long-term emissions goals.
